'Globalization - Rebalancing act between the west and the rest'! Its very intriguing how this view is so different from how anti-globalization activists from neo-global economies view this phase in history. In India, Globalization is often the big reason for creation of ghost towns, gaps between have and have nots and polarized progress.                                                                                     
The point made here is so relevant when we look at how we & partner centers struggle to place students in smaller towns and how even moving from a point of not having enough to a place with opportunities is itself a great big previlage!
So relevant for our context - the whole conversation around places as beauty contestants and ghost towns!

Do you what are Exact **Goals of Digital Literacy**. And what we are trying to teach our students about Digital Literacy. Please  have a look at below

  

***Find**–* Help young people learn *where* and *how* to find reliable sources. This includes search engines for research, but also legal platforms for downloading music and art.

***Sort**-*- Help young people learn how to identify relevant information for their project or research.

***Evaluate***– Help young people learn how to determine the value of a source. This includes: credibility, reliability, authority (of the author, publisher, organization, study, or media).

***Manage***– Help children know and understand how to use information. For example, how to properly cite a source, how to apply copyright or creative commons laws, or how to safely and legally download media files (including music).

***Create***– Help children know how to create their own work without plagiarizing or infringing on the copyright of other works.

Thanks for sharing, Manjunth! Very useful! Are we able to achieve all the steps in our classrooms? 🤔

I think we are able to achieve steps 1  (Find) and 2 (Sort) quite well. But we can put more effort for steps 3, 4, 5, I think! 😅

As a facilitator/ trainer are you okay with the students eating, sitting on bench while you take the class?
What do you think? M S Mahala
This is amazing and creates a space for students where they can discuss their concerns, challenges and can have open dialogs.
Azmat is it your class? amazing, What was students reactions to such environments in classroom?
Jaya Verma Sushmitha Rosline Rakesh YadavDeepak Saini Suraj Choudhary
Totally ok with it, if a student does it with giving attention to my class.
Attention will be diverted. Some discipline is required to do any kind of work  or their is some etiquette of learning  ....

I don't mind giving my students lil eating break ,I always give freedom of eating in my classroom with only one condition they will be attentive and actively participating.Its quite common with the age group with whom we are working to give them space and feeling of freedom.Giving them 5- 10 mins of break may not affect our work but will definitely gives our student happiness!!

If I see through lens of giving liberty, creating space for learning and fearless environment for learner than I can say "Students are attentive and indulge in some learning assignment" but If I see students from lens of something called discipline and behavior than my response would be different. Azmat this challenges might be faced by many facilitators who are working in government ITIs esp. when principal show this in real situation at your class than he/she might be angry. What we do to handle situation or how do we convenience him/her about facilitation and creating learning space for Learner?
Yes idea gud but I don't think so in India this will  be done..

Personally, I'd prefer giving a mini break if people are hungry, than giving the class complete liberty to pull out their lunch whenever. Food can be a distraction to others (me included :) 

In terms of sitting in all sorts of places, I'm cool with it provided they are engaged and participative. If they do need a sleep break, that's cool too!

I wouldn't personally encourage eating or sitting on benches, in general as I feel it brings a certain casualness to one's mind and can influence others in a similar way.  But instead I would be happy to allot some unsupervised time where they are free to conduct an  exercise/assignment/group discussion or exercise, etc in the way they would like to.

I'd say eating is fine as long as they don't eat and finish someone else's food :)

Sitting on the desk is like standing or sitting on the floor....as long as it aids group work and doesn't obstruct someone else's work I guess it's okay.

When we say liberty and rights the Facilitators also do have them and it should also be respected... I think if a facilitator bcoms uncomfortable when the things in the pics are happening then s/he has not done the community agreement (group norms) part effectively...S/he has to take a pause and redo the group norms again and also stress the fact that the facilitator is also part of the group...Her/His rights, wishes, teaching/learning style also needs space and only a facilitator can create that space for themselves...

I would err on the side of conservative opinion and say it is better not to have such behavior ...giving them break is fine, but when students start eating and then work , neither will they eat properly nor will they work well.there are some practical problems , also what if unfortunately some may choke on their food? And more than the work , the food becomes a priority? One of my group norms in a session is respect ...and when we say respect , it also applies to the space where we work  , apart from respecting others ..and giving undivided attention to the learning space is respecting it...

Hi All, in the first picture, i see only one student eating, but she is also focusing, she would have not got time to have her ( breakfast )/food, so why don't we understand the situation and let go. I am sure even students know how to behave, sometimes they might have taken permission too, isn't it.

Hi All, in the second picture, one of the student is sitting on the bench, what i could visualize is that, having one student writing or discussing, their is not enough space for all the students to comfortably listen to it and hence one of the student found her spot, but keen in learning/understanding. If it was a lecture type in classroom, i don't think any student will sit on bench. Being Facilitators we should think from their cap too! This is my point of view...

Here's a question

What do you do when an ITI student tells you she or he wants to **quit the course**? What are the steps you take?

One thing I would do is try to understand the reasons and connect them to the respective centre teachers who can help in giving a better guidance. Since the student has approached me, I will make sure I am present whenever the student talks to his/her ITI teachers for guidance and make sure that he / she is not forced to do anything.  

Will also try to find out possible solutions to the issues or concerns the student has and will communicate them to the student and help him/her decide wisely. If the student still wants to leave the course then will help the student to find the best possible alternatives and guide them in the new course or path he/she wishes to pursue.  Will also try and make sure that the parents are also not pressurizing the student.
M S Mahala

Digital job fair.

HireMee is a web portal that aims to ensure that bright young graduates from colleges across India are discovered by companies. Colleges can also improve their placement records using this portal.

HireMee provides a mobile app that allows students to upload video profiles for a more personal touch to their resumes and also conducts skill assessments that are put together by experts in each domain and award students with a 7-digit score that goes into their pre-assessed profiles. This combination of a pre-assessed resume, a skill assessment test and video profile gives companies and recruiters a comprehensive idea of each candidate. They can shortlist candidates based on their requirements directly from HireMee website or mobile app.

Helping students find their dream job and creating great job openings for freshers, companies find the right employees and helping colleges ensure better placement records is the objective. HireMee services are completely free and are aimed towards ensuring students from all over India get a chance to find their dream job.

One of my students studying in medical electronics desperately wants a** trade specific fresher job**. But, She has** low technical aptitude** ability. She also have **below average academics**. But because of her **good communication skills**, she can get** job in retail or call centre.**
1. **Shall I advice her for these jobs? Please 'Poll'**
1. **How should I convey her? Please 'comment below'**

Hi Azmat, has she done the interest and ability activity ? I think instead of convincing, it would be good to make her realise her abilities and interest and help her make a decision.   Since you mentioned, she is desperately wants a job in the same trade, it shows her interest to pursue the career in same line.  She might not have technical abilities, which she need to work on.  Once she builds her technical aptitude with her present good communication skills, she might get a good opportunity in the same trade.  Academic performance hardly matters in an interview scenario. Happy to know your and other trainers view on this.

Does she desperately need a job?

I also think sometimes simply waiting for the perfect job can have one lose a lot of good opportunities on the way.

Definitely you should help her explore new sectors as well. Then she can make an informed decision.
I absolutely agree with Kotresh HB

I think you can suggest her to join a call center job or their are various other jobs that are relevant for someone with good communication skills; jobs such as public speaker, media person. i partially agree with Kotresh that it depends on her interests. we can suggest her few professions that will be good for her considering her communication skills.

I'd ask her to research the following: 
1) What sort of jobs are available in the medical electronics space
2) What skills are needed for these job roles
3) Meet 2-3 alumni from the sector or few professionals who have 1-3 years of experience in the ME sector and understand what life's like, why do they well at their work, if they struggle then why etc
What finally happened Azmat?

Facilitators in Vocational Training center or ITI are also doing many things other than running sessions. Before we know it, our semester/batches are coming to an end. and lots of syllabus is leftover what should we do in this situation so, trainee would not suffer after he/she pass out their courses?
take classes morning 1 session and evening 1 session, ask your another facilitator to help you to complete syllabus
I'd also make a resolution to make a good plan for next sem and try to be as assertive and creative about it, when getting additional responsibilities.

Hello Folks ! Here is a picture for you all. It needs some decoding and explanation. What is it trying to convey ? If anything strikes you Comment down below. There is no specific answer. All comments are welcome.
It tells about our Education System , Confused !!!
How ideas & moods & thoughts are passed amongst people - how we all influence each other?

To me this is about how we pass on things from one person/generation to the other without questioning or thinking why we are doing that. Same is the case in our education system to some extent - continue to learn content/skills which might not be relevant for today but no one will question it or change it.

Parent to child, child to community.

So much potential for a parent to transfer the good to a community 

So much potential for a teacher to gauge, assess and encourage/display the good in a classroom, thereby influencing a community.

This series of images talks about two aspects atleast. One is the herd mentality. Simply following what others say/do without critical thinking/questioning/understanding the big picture when required. And the other is the power of the written word.

DON'T READ 
Viktor Frankl, one of the great psychiatrists of the twentieth century, survived the death camps of Nazi Germany. 
His little book, Man’s Search for Meaning, is one of those life-changing books that everyone should read.
Frankl once told the story of a woman who called him in the middle of the night to calmly inform him she was about to commit suicide.
Frankl kept her on the phone and talked her through her depression, giving her reason after reason to carry on living. 
Finally she promised she would not take her life, and she kept her word.
When they later met, Frankl asked which reason had persuaded her to live?
"None of them", she told him.
What then influenced her to go on living, he pressed?
Her answer was simple, it was Frankl’s *willingness to listen* to her in the middle of the night. 
A world in which there was someone ready to listen to another's pain seemed to her a world in which it was worthwhile to live.
Often, it is not the brilliant argument that makes the difference. 
Sometimes the *small act of listening* is the greatest gift we can give.

Such a beautiful post, Jintha. Listening is unfortunately a highly underrated skill in today's world even if it has the potential to save lives! We at Trainer Tribe however believe it is critical for a facilitator to be able to listen and respond favorably when conducting a training as well as outside the classroom.

Hi Joel! Great post as usual :) Can you please explain more on derivative idea?

Hi Jeevan Kumar This explanation will give you new insights about Derivative Ideas.

It Simply means Copy of an Idea or Product Which Already Exists in the Market.
Derivative Idea = Copied / Imitated Idea

For Example:

Many of the applications we get are imitations of some existing company. That's one source of ideas, but not the best. If you look at the origins of successful startups, few were started in imitation of some other startup. Where did they get their ideas? Usually from some specific, unsolved problem the founders identified.

Apple happened because Steve Wozniak wanted a computer, Google because Larry and Sergey couldn't find stuff online, Hotmail because Sabeer Bhatia and Jack Smith couldn't exchange email at work.

So Instead of copying the Facebook, with some variation that the Facebook rightly ignored, look for ideas from the other direction. Instead of starting from companies and working back to the problems they solved, look for problems and imagine the company that might solve them.
Why a single founder is a mistake for an start-up?

Ayush This will be the reason Why Single Founder is considered as Mistake.

Have you ever noticed how few successful startups were founded by just one person? Even companies you think of as having one founder, like Oracle, usually turn out to have more. It seems unlikely this is a coincidence.

What's wrong with having one founder? To start with, it's a vote of no confidence. It probably means the founder couldn't talk any of his friends into starting the company with him. That's pretty alarming, because his friends are the ones who know him best.

But even if the founder's friends were all wrong and the company is a good bet, he's still at a disadvantage. Starting a startup is too hard for one person. Even if you could do all the work yourself, you need colleagues to brainstorm with, to talk you out of stupid decisions, and to cheer you up when things go wrong.

The last one might be the most important. The low points in a startup are so low that few could bear them alone. When you have multiple founders, esprit de corps binds them together in a way that seems to violate conservation laws. Each thinks "I can't let my friends down." This is one of the most powerful forces in human nature, and it's missing when there's just one founder.

**Tips for aspiring entrepreneurs**

 

If you're ready to enter the world of entrepreneurship, here are five important tips from experts to keep in mind.

**Learn from others' failures.** Rather than admiring the small percentage of businesses that grow to become successful, study those that end up failing. Gottlieb said this research would greatly increase your chances of success, because most companies have made common mistakes that have led to their demise. He said that having the humility to learn from the mistakes of others before making them yourself is the secret to success.

**Make sure this is what you want.** Because entrepreneurship entails so much hard work, it is critical to ensure you're following the right path,

"If this is something you really want, then think long term, and be persistent," she said. "The vast majority of great entrepreneurs failed multiple times before they finally found the business idea that took off and brought them success."

**Solve problems.** Entrepreneurs should always be in search of problems to solve and not the other way around, . In other words, "they should not start with a solution looking for a problem," he said.

**Be passionate.** Successful entrepreneurs are driven primarily by a need for achievement and the desire to make a meaningful difference, Bachenheimer said. "The most important traits are passion and persistence, but these must not be confused with arrogance and stubbornness," he said.

**Get advice from those who have done it.**  business owners to find mentors who are successful, in addition to reading books, networking with people they admire and looking into great education programs to help them throughout the process.

Just follow the Quest curriculum blindly it is best way to teach basic English .

Amazing to see the different views here :  using the local language to build the context and then translating it into English , following QA 's digital content in various platforms including mobile app ,start from basic , easy English sentences so that they can build their confidence, tell them to use only English when they chat in phones, make them participate in role plays in English and show documentaries in English, tell them that English is as easy as local language - to remove the fear ..overall the sense I am getting is we have to simplify the language , understand where the students are and deliver it at that level. We have to also push them to practice more in English without any fear and make the learning process interesting by sharing interesting videos and making them participate in dramas .

@ Jintha : the one technique that I used to follow is speak only in English in the class. It does not matter if the students speak back to me in their mother-tongue but  I would speak only in English and they would start doing that. Also, if the students are not able to understand my English , I would ask those who are relatively better in the language to translate my sentences for them.

Today conducted a guest session on Health, Nutrition & Menstruation Cycle for "girls student of GOVT ITI, Ajmer.  One of the main objective  of  this session was "to create an understanding about health and awareness  about menstruation cycle."

**Topics were-: **

1.Health,its importance and factors affecting health

2. Nutrition, deficiency of nutrition and Balanced diet

3. An important topic was also covered with the context of women/girls, that was about  the **anemia, menstruation cycle, hygiene during periods and myths about periods in our society. ** 

**Feedback from students-: ** Before  this session I tried to talk about this with girls and I got to know that they are unaware about the menstruation cycle, why it happen with them/only with girls. That time I also found hesitation in them. some of them started smiling.   

After the session girls said that they got to know about their  body, importance and process of menstruation cycle, hygiene during periods time & myths about periods in our society.

One interesting brainstorming activity done by Gurjeet mam with students by asking simple questions of day to day life like

If chicken is ordered or made and only one tangdi (leg pcs) pcs is available who will eat in your home or who will have chance to eat at your home?
Mother or father

When girls are allowed to wear shirts and jeans, why boys are not allowed to wear sarees and bangles?
When we were kids we wished to wear bangles by looking their vibrant color but then our family members always tried and convinced us by saying this is item of girls, you are a boy you are not allowed to wear.
From very start we were taught and conditioned like there is huge difference between boy and girl.

But there is no such thing like that, the only difference is our reproductive organs apart from it we all are humans.

Students thought and replied themselves after sometime that yes there is so much of inequality in small small aspects in our life.

We have to start from at our home first...we need to observe and address each and every thing that is happening at our home and try to question ourselves "why"?

There were many questions asked to students they were amazed to know that.

It was very interesting session.
